value: caption=Greifswald retained much of its historic charm, here depited by Caspar David Friedrich

. Greifswald is a very old town and gained city rights as early as 1240. In 1278, Greifswald became a part of the Hanseatic network and in 1456, the university was founded.

From 1648 to 1815, Greifswald was a part of

's northern German territories. Following the Second World War, the town became a part of the Soviet occupation zone. The town faired rather well during and after the war, but during the Soviet and East German reign, the economy and infrastructure declined. Following the reunion of the two German states, huge sums of money has been pumped into the area to help improve the situation and to lower the unemployment rates.
The easiest way to get to Greifswald is probably by car, but there are other options. Going by air is restricted to season.
There are no regular flights to the area. From May to September,
runs services during roughly the same time from
ran a service betweev Usedom and

during the autumn of 2011, but it is unclear whether the service will come back.

The service is only upheld on Saturdays. There is a transfer from the airport to the seaside resorts of Ahlbeck, Heringsdorf and Bansin. Transer is booked via the airport. The only way to get to Greifswald from the airport is by cab or rental car, which may be booked through the airport service, phone +49 3837 62 97 34, fax +49 3837 62 98 75 3. There are plans to extend the
(see below) to the airport during 2012, but until those plans come true, you have to get off at Usedom station and catch a cab to the airport.
, operates trains to and from Greifswald. The journey from Berlin takes about 2 h 45 min and the ticket is ca €32. A ticket from

is about €9 and takes roughly 20 minutes. Tickets may be purchased on board (Note: only on inter-city trains, additional fees apply) at railway stations, in ticket machines, through the web page of Die Bahn or through their call center, phone: +491805996633

value: From north: Road 251 from Stralsund. This is a ring road around Greifswald, so to get into the town, turn off into road B96/B109.
From south: E251. Trun off into B96/B109 and B109 leads to the town center

. Three major ship-owners operates ferries to and from Sassnitz:
The town center is small and the streets are narrow, which makes it better to park the car on the outskirts and walk.
runs the six (1, 4, 5, 6, 7 och 20) bus lines in Greifswald. All lines, except nr 5, leave from and/or pass the bus station (
) in the western part of the town centre. Note that the lines may take different routes depending on time and day.

value: Line 1: ZOB - Bahnhof Süd (Greifswalds southern railway station) - Galgenkampwiesen (Neuer Friedhof, The New Cemetery)
Line 5: Wieck-Ostseeviertel - Schönwalde I/II - EKZ, Elisen Park – Bahnhof Süd - Schillerplatz-Galgenkampwiesen.

The town center is small with narrow streets. It is better to park the car and walk. If you want to rent a car, you can do it here:

value: , Stralsunder Strasse 27-30. Phone: 03834-50 88 10. Open: Mon.Fri 0800-1800, Sat 0900-1200. Closed on Sundays.

There are quite a few recurring events worth visiting:

value: : local artists open their workshops to the public (Whitsuntide)
, featuring dragon boats (third weekend in June)
name=The festival for Polish cultur, music, litterature and art
, including a Christmas market with handicraft, pottery and 70 different cultural events (Advent Sunday and onwards)

at Schuhhagen 2. The general currency, as in the rest of Germany, is euro. Most credit cards are accepted, but always check before you buy - some restaurants or smaller shops do not accept credit cards.
in central Greifswald has about 30 shops, a bowling alley and a cinema.
content=Is a shopping mall with around 40 shops, cafés and restaurants. Most shops are open Mon-Fri 0900-2000, Sat 0900-1800. Closed on Sundays.

content=This restaurant, situated in the hotel with the same name and on the very edge of the town center, next to the river Ryck, has a big and tasty menu. The guest may choose to sit in the bar or in the restaurant, parts of which has glass walls and roof.
content=Jambo is an african theme restaurant, next door to Alter Speicher.

content=This restaurant is a must for the fish lover. Greifswald is only a few minutes from the sea, which makes the fish as fresh as can be. Please note that the restaurant does not accept credit cards.

content=Wirtshaus Wallensteinkeller is part of a small chain with restaurants in Stralsund, Wolgast and Neubrandenburg. The chain is trying to create an environment reminding the guest about the days of Albrecht von Wallenstein, i.e. the Thirty Years' War 1618-1648.

content=Zum alten Fritz is a pub at the very heart of the town center, on the town square Am Markt. Apart from the local beer, snacks and light meals are served. Should you want to try all the beers available, why not order "Ein Meter Bier", i.e. "One Meter of Beer". You get a plank, a meter in length, with eleven small glasses.

content=Four star business hotel situated in the outskirts of the town center, with approximately 10 minutes walk to the market place. This hotel has a restaurant, a bar, conference facilities and a sauna. All rooms are equipped with cable TV, telephone, hair dryer, trouser press and wireless internet. Pets allowed (extra fees), but with restrictions.
content=Small hotel in the city center. Eight double rooms and three single rooms, all with WC and shower/bath, mini bar, telephone, TV and radio. No restaurant, only breakfast is served.
content=A nice little hotel with 8 rooms: 4 double and 4 single rooms, all equipped with WC and shower or bath and a TV. The restaurant is focused on the turkish and mediterranean kitchens.

content=Mercure Hotel Greifswald Am Gorzberg is a middle range/business hotel on the southwest outskirts of town. The hotel has a bar, a sauna and solarium. Breakfast is served in the restaurant. The hotel has 113 rooms, all with a minibar and telephone.

content=this is a small but newly refurbished (2009) hotel in a building from around 1790. The reception is open 0800-1800. The hotel has 18 rooms, a mediterreanean-style bar which also serves light snacks and a beer garden.
content=This hotel, situated in the southern parts of the town, is mainly aimed at business travellers. The hotel has a bar, restaurant and meeting facilities.

content=The hotel is a hotel aimed at families and has 122 rooms and 48 flats/family rooms. It is situated in the southwest outskirts of Greifswald, not far from the railway station Greifswald Süd, and features its own bar and restaurant.
content=Alter Speicher is a nice middle-range hotel only a couple of minutes walk from the town square. Own bar and restaurant overlooking the river Ryck and the museum harbour.

The town has excellent coverage for both 2G and 3G.

value: content=Mühlenstrasse 25-26.  Open 7 days a week, generous opening hours

The fishing village Wieck, today more or less a part of Greifswald, lies only a few kilometres east of the city center. This is a nice little village, featuring an old village center and the ruin of the monastery of Eldena, destroyed by Swedish forces in the 1600s.
